Award.AwardTitle: Toward a Theory of Innovation in Emerging Economies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Existing theories of innovative organizations have been based on the experience of firms in developed economies. Consequently, these theories take certain "minimal" institutional environments as given, and build their insights and explanations upon the framework of these assumptions. Some theorists go so far as to claim that without these pre-conditions, innovation is not possible. Thus the institutional characteristics of developed nations are described as necessary -- if not sufficient -- ingredients for innovation. In contrast, evidence from high technology firms in developing countries demonstrates not only that firms operating without such institutions can innovate, but also that innovative organizations can thrive in environments considered hostile to innovation and entrepreneurship.

Despite their obvious innovative accomplishments, the institutional environments, uncertainty, and risks faced by these organizations differ greatly from those in the developed countries. This research project will develop a theory that explains the rise, behavior, and capability development of innovative organizations in a particular emerging economy: China. The aim is to build a theory useful for understanding and better predicting: i) the innovative output of high technology organizations given their set of firm-level capabilities and the institutional structure of their operating environment; ii) the types of capabilities these firms are likely, and unlikely, to develop; iii) the relationship of these capabilities to their innovative performance; and iv) given a set of capabilities and institutions, their likely development trajectory. The latter can be better used to aggregate from the firm level to the national or regional level, adding to a more accurate understanding of innovative and economic performance in emerging economies.

In addition to the intellectual contributions described above, the data and findings from this project should be of use to managers and policy makers seeking to ensure innovation and competitiveness in the context of rapidly globalizing supply chains.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the last three decades scholarly research has significantly advanced our understating of the sources and causes of innovation. However, the existing theories of innovation are based on the experience of firms in developed economies. While existing research emphasizes the conditions in developed economies, evidence from high technology firms in developing countries demonstrates not only that firms can innovate in environments without developed country institutions but also that innovation can thrive in environments considered hostile to innovation.

This NSF research has taken a first step toward developing a theory that explains the rise, behavior, and capability development of innovative organizations in emerging economies. In order to develop such a theory this project utilized China as the critical case study. Our aim was to begin construction of a theory useful for understanding and better predicting: i) the innovative output of high technology organizations given their set of firm-level capabilities and the institutional structure of their operating environment; ii) the types of capabilities these firms are likely, and unlikely, to develop; iii) the relationship of these capabilities to their innovative performance; and iv) given a set of capabilities and institutions, their likely development trajectory. This last point in particular can be used to build a clear understanding of how innovative firms are in emerging economies and hence the types of competitive challenges they pose.

Our research has uncovered much about China’s capabilities in innovation as a result of its condition of structured uncertainty. Structured uncertainty constrains the ability of Chinese firms to create novel innovations regardless of the amount of funding provided. At the same time, however, the incentives under structured uncertainty mean there is strong support for entrepreneurial ventures and incremental innovations. The result is a robust innovation system, one plugged into and complementary with the broader global economy.

Our work on technology standards in China has helped account for the causes of national differences in markets for technology. In China, the powerful central state attempts to direct standardization activity, but firms have developed innovation capabilities suited to improvements in established technologies or for improvements in production. The result is an extreme difficulty setting internationally influential technology standards and a continued reliance by Chinese firms on foreign technologies, even as the overall sophistication of Chinese enterprises increases. Under structured uncertainty, standard setting is extremely difficult as firms seek to harmonize with international trends rather than create them. This research has been jointly sponsored by the Senate US-China Economic and Security Review Commission and the National Academies.

In four years of research, we have seen these innovation trends repeated in multiple industries. In China’s construction industry, we found that China’s complex government registration system leads firms to borrow licensed companies’ registrations in order to bid on projects. This arrangement enables entrepreneurs to quickly launch new firms. However, because these “hang on” enterprises are removed from formal business channels and their profit margins are thinner, new innovations such as energy saving technologies or “green” materials are more difficult to transfer. Our study of innovation in the mobile phone handset sector found that local government support was essential to sustaining the industry.
